description:
Gerris buenoi, commonly known as Bueno's water strider, is a species of water strider found in North America. It belongs to the family Gerridae, which are a group of semiaquatic insects that can walk on the surface of water.

Gerris buenoi is a small insect, typically measuring between 7-10 millimeters in length. It has a slender, elongated body and long, thin legs that allow it to effortlessly glide across the surface of ponds, lakes, and slow-moving streams. The species is characterized by its dark brown or black coloration, with occasional lighter markings on the abdomen and legs.

These water striders are adept at using the surface tension of water to their advantage, using their specialized feet to propel themselves across the water's surface in search of prey. They primarily feed on smaller aquatic insects, such as midges and mosquito larvae, which they capture using their raptorial front legs.

Gerris buenoi plays an important role in the aquatic ecosystem, serving as both a predator and a prey species. They are an integral part of the food web, providing a link between aquatic and terrestrial environments.
